questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain for 3 days. Physical examination shows guarding and tenderness to palpation over the left lower abdomen. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. A CT scan of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the patient's imaging findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Failed neural crest cell migration is implicated in the development of Hirschsprung disease. This manifests early in life with failure to pass meconium within 48 hours of birth, followed by constipation, megacolon, and explosive stools when manually disimpacted. It would not be first observed in a 68-year-old woman, and a megacolon is not seen on this CT scan. Neural crest cells are not involved in the development of the kidneys. They are, however, involved in the formation of the adrenal medulla of the adrenal glands, which are not shown in this image.

B) INCORRECT:

Absent tissue differentiation accounts for several abdominal pathologies such as renal aplasia and uterine hypoplasia. However, the horseshoe kidney seen in this CT image is composed of properly differentiated renal tissue.

C) INCORRECT:

Abnormal organ rotation is the cause of an annular pancreas. Normal pancreatic anatomy results from the merging of dorsal and ventral buds. If the ventral bud fails to appropriately rotate, it can form a ring of pancreas around the duodenum, an annular pancreas. Annular pancreas can cause epigastric abdominal pain due to bowel obstruction, but the pancreas is not visualized on this CT scan cut.

D) INCORRECT:

Incomplete organ fusion can cause uterine pathology. Normal uterine development involves the independent fusion of the upper and lower paramesonephric ducts. Failure of the upper ducts to fuse results in a bicornuate uterus. While this can lead to pregnancy-related complications, the patient in this question is older than child-bearing age and the CT scan does not visualize her uterus.

E) INCORRECT:

Abnormal outpouching of a hollow organ describes colonic diverticula. These are transmuscular pockets that are commonly observed in the colon. As they are blind ends within a generally motile bowel, luminal contents that get caught in these pockets and become infected can lead to significant abdominal pain and rectal bleeding. This patient's presentation may be attributable to diverticulitis but no diverticula are present in the CT scan cut shown.

F) CORRECT:

Impaired organ ascent explains the presence of this horseshoe kidney at an inferior position relative to normal kidneys. The fused inferior poles of the horseshoe kidneys get caught under the inferior mesenteric artery, impeding the normal ascension of the kidneys to their retroperitoneal locations. However, this obstructed migration is generally benign, does not affect kidney function, and is not commonly associated with ischemia or abdominal pain. This radiographic finding is most likely incidental and not associated with this patient's current complaint.
Image Description:

Congenital abnormality of the kidney. Ventral view.
questions.hint: This patient's CT scan shows a horseshoe kidney. Her abdominal symptoms are likely unrelated to the renal pathology as a horseshoe kidney is often an incidental finding.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the effects of an antihypertensive drug during pregnancy. Follow-up studies show that the drug can adversely affect differentiation of the ureteric bud into its direct derivatives in fetuses exposed during the first trimester. Which of the following structures is most likely to develop incorrectly in the affected fetus?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The distal convoluted tubule is part of the excretory system, which originates from the metanephric mesenchyme – not the ureteric bud. The distal convoluted tubule does, however, represent the connecting point between direct derivatives of the metanephric mesenchyme and those that originate from the ureteric bud.

B) INCORRECT:

The Bowman's capsule is part of the excretory system of the kidney, which originates from the metanephric mesenchyme – not the ureteric bud.

C) CORRECT:

The collecting duct system, consisting of the collecting ducts and tubules, ureter, renal pelvis, major calyces, and minor calyces, develop from the ureteric bud. A defective ureteric bud would thus likely cause these structures to develop incorrectly.
Image Description:

The pronephros is the first nephric stage in humans but does not contribute to the development of the kidney. It degenerates by the 5th week of intrauterine life.

The mesonephros functions as a temporary excretory system during the first trimester. It degenerates once the fetal kidneys have developed. The mesonephric duct (Wolffian duct) persists, developing into the ejaculatory duct, ductus deferens, epididymis, and seminal vesicles in males. The ureteric bud arises from the mesonephric duct and branches into the metanephric kidney to form the collecting tubules, the renal pelvis, and the ureter.
The metanephros arises from the intermediate mesoderm caudal to the mesonephros in the 5th week of development and differentiates into the functional kidney.

D) INCORRECT:

The bladder develops from the upper part of the urogenital sinus, which is also connected to the allantois. Over time, the allantois obliterates and ultimately becomes the median umbilical ligament after birth.

E) INCORRECT:

The Loop of Henle is part of the excretory system of the kidney, which originates from the metanephric mesenchyme – not the ureteric bud.

F) INCORRECT:

The proximal convoluted tubule is part of the excretory system of the kidney, which originates from the metanephric mesenchyme – not the ureteric bud.
questions.hint: The ureteric bud originates from the caudal end of the mesonephric duct during the 5th week of fetal development and induces differentiation of the metanephric mesenchyme. The ureteric bud and metanephric mesenchyme together form the metanephros.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of decreased appetite and abdominal pain for the last several weeks. Physical examination shows a palpable left-sided abdominal mass that does not cross the midline. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a large, necrotic tumor on the left kidney. Histological examination of the kidney mass shows primitive blastemal cells and immature tubules and glomeruli. This tissue is most likely derived from the same embryological structure as which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The carotid body contains cells derived from the neural crest. Neural crest cells form specialized structures, such as the sympathetic ganglia, the adrenal medulla, and melanocytes. This patient's tumor is derived from renal progenitor cells, not neural crest cells.

B) INCORRECT:

The adrenal medulla is derived from neural crest cells. Neural crest cells originate from the neuroectoderm and give rise to structures of the PNS (e.g., ganglia, cranial nerves, Schwann cells), and other cells such as melanocytes and odontoblasts. Renal progenitor cells that form the tumor in this patient are not derived from neural crest cells.

The adrenal cortex is derived from mesoderm.

C) INCORRECT:

The thyroid gland parenchyma consists of follicular cells and parafollicular cells (C cells), which are derived from endodermal cells of the floor of the pharynx. The endoderm also gives rise to the pharyngeal pouches, the epithelium of the stomach and intestine, and the pancreas, liver, and gallbladder. Renal progenitor cells that form the tumor in this patient are not derived from the endoderm.

D) CORRECT:

The papillary muscles of the heart are derived from the mesoderm. The mesoderm is the embryonic progenitor of all muscles (cardiac muscle, smooth muscle, and skeletal muscle), the kidneys, ureters, vessels, bone, cartilage, and many cells of the reproductive system. This patient's nephroblastoma is a tumor of renal progenitor cells.

Formation of the aorticopulmonary septum from the truncus arteriosus and bulbus cordis, and thus the development of the aorta and pulmonary trunks, involves caudal migration of the neural crest cells.
Image Description:

Adult derivatives of mesoderm (not all derivatives are shown)

Paraxial mesoderm derivatives include the vertebrae, annulus fibrosus of the intervertebral discs, and ribs.

Lateral plate mesoderm derivatives include the heart.

Intermediate mesoderm derivatives include the kidneys.

Somatic (somatopleuric) mesoderm derivatives include parietal (outer) pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal linings.

Splanchnic mesoderm derivatives include connective tissue and smooth muscle of the intestinal wall, and visceral (inner) pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal linings.

E) INCORRECT:

The anterior pituitary gland originates from the surface ectoderm. The surface ectoderm is a germ layer derived from the ectoderm. It gives rise to the epidermis, hair, nails, inner ear, external ear, tooth enamel, eye lens, anterior pituitary, parotid gland, and anal canal (below the pectinate line). This patient's tumor histology indicates the embryological source as primitive renal cells, which are not derived from the ectoderm.
questions.hint: Nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor) is a tumor comprised of renal progenitor cells, including rhabdomyoblasts. Embryologically, the kidneys derive from the mesoderm.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after presenting with elevated blood pressures on both arms at a routine visit 1 month ago. He feels well and takes no medications. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 99 kg (218 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 148/85 mm Hg on the right arm and 152/87 mm Hg on the left arm. Physical examination and laboratory studies show no abnormalities. The physician recommends lifestyle modifications in combination with treatment with hydrochlorothiazide. From which of the following embryological tissues does the site of action of this drug arise?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The ureteric bud is part of the metanephros, the last of the three embryonic kidneys, which arises during the 5th week of embryonic development. The ureteric bud originates from the caudal end of the mesonephric duct and differentiates into the ureter, renal pelvis, major calyces, minor calyces, and collecting ducts. It does not develop into the distal convoluted tubule.

B) CORRECT:

The metanephric blastema is part of the metanephros, the last of the three embryonic kidneys, which arises during the 5th week of embryonic development. Induced by the ureteric bud, the metanephric blastema differentiates into the glomerulus, proximal convoluted tubule, loop of Henle, and the distal convoluted tubule, which is the site of action of hydrochlorothiazide.

C) INCORRECT:

The mesonephric (Wolffian) duct, a part of the mesonephros, differentiates into several structures in the male reproductive system (epididymis, ductus deferens, seminal vesicle, and ejaculatory duct). In female embryos, this structure degenerates because of a lack of stimulation by testosterone. The mesonephric duct does not develop into mature renal tissue.

D) INCORRECT:

The pronephros, the first precursor of the developing kidney, arises in the cervical region of the embryo during the 4th week of embryonic development and migrates caudally to connect with the pronephric duct. The pronephros is composed of nephrotomes and nephric tubules and has a temporary excretory function. However, it degenerates completely before the 5th week of embryonic development and, therefore, does not develop into mature renal tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

The mesonephros, the second of the three embryonic kidneys, functions as a temporary excretory system during the first trimester. Once the fetal kidneys have developed, the majority of the mesonephros degenerates; therefore, it does not develop into mature renal tissue. The caudal part of the mesonephros contributes to the mesonephric duct to form the ejaculatory duct, ductus deferens, epididymis, and seminal vesicles.
questions.hint: Thiazide diuretics such as hydrochlorothiazide decrease blood pressure by inhibiting the Na+-Cl- cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule.
